III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.10107 Employment policies and procedures;
Section establishment.
Description A facility shall establish and follow written employment
policies and procedures that shall assure that staff are
1

emotionally stable and of suitable health, ability,
experience, and education to perform the duties assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member was watching female youth shower and
commenting on their bodies.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 03/03/2023 and did not
have any further information to provide.
Youth A's parent was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. She
stated that she had heard from her daughter that someone with
the same last name as Staff 1 I had said something to Youth A
that made her uncomfortable after showering.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. Youth A
was able to describe a specific staff member, and eventually
stated it was Staff 1 that has made her uncomfortable during her
time placed at the facility. She stated that she felt like he looked at
her inappropriately when he did visuals in their rooms and after
showers. Youth A clarified that she didn’t think he or any other
staff had ever looked into the shower area when she was in there.
Youth A described this as “weird vibes”. Youth A confirmed that
Staff 1 had never touched her or said anything sexually explicit to
her but specified that she just felt like he looked at her funny, and
that there were other youth that felt the same.
Administrator 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. She
provided documentation on the facility’s shower policy for
employees and provided a tour of one of the units to view the
shower area. Each unit has a separated shower area because
the individual rooms have bathrooms for youth’s use. The shower
area is accessed behind a door with a window in it. That window
has a cover on the outside of the door that staff use to provide
privacy to the youth showering. It was described that two staff are
always present during showering, one at the door facing away
from the window and another elsewhere in the unit. They then
only enter the shower area after the youth has clothed and exited
in order to disinfect for the next use.
Youth B was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/15/2023. She stated Staff 1 made comments in her time
placed at the facility that made her uncomfortable. She stated that
she heard Staff 1 say to her “I like your smile” on a couple
2

different occasions as an example. Youth B also felt like Staff 1
stared at her at times. Youth B recalled that Staff 1 worked the
shower shifts often. She stated that Staff 1 never went into the
shower area during times it was being used, nor did any other
staff.
Youth C was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/15/2023. She stated that she had no concerns with the
procedure used for showering at the facility and that she didn’t
think any staff had ever looked into the shower area when she
was in there. She could not recall a time that the window was not
covered or that her privacy felt invaded in anyway. Youth C did
refer to Staff 1 as someone that has made “weird comments” in
the past, such as something to the effect of “I like your hair down,
it is pretty” or calling her a “good girl” when she followed
directions. Youth C confirmed that Staff 1 never touched her or
did anything else inappropriate, nor have any other staff. Youth C
stated that she has never filed a grievance with the facility in
response to any of these comments.
Youth D was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/15/2023. Youth D had similar anecdotes to share as other
youth, stating that she has heard Staff 1 use the phrase “good girl”
to herself and other youth while placed at the facility Youth D did
not state that she encountered staff looking in to the shower area.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/15/2023. Staff 1 denied ever having done anything
inappropriate to any youth that has been placed at the facility. He
stated that he has worked there for years and that this is the first
time he has heard of such allegations, but no one made them
directly to him. Staff 1 admitted that it is possible that his positive
attitude towards the youth could be misconstrued, and also that he
works hard to have all youth follow the rules of the facility and this
would not be the first time there were youth placed that had a
problem with him in that regard. Staff 1 stated that he has never
touched a youth inappropriately nor has he intentionally looked at
any youth inappropriately. He stated he does work the shower
process at times in the male and female units but that the process
is designed as such to not allow any staff to see youth as they are
getting out of the shower or getting dressed.
Documents reviewed:
• The personnel file of Staff 1 was reviewed and had no
incidents of discipline that would cause concern in this
investigation.
3

• An internal investigation conducted and authored by
Supervisor 1 dated 03/02/2023 was reviewed. In this
investigation allegations were presented by Youth A about
a staff member that may have viewed her in the shower,
but Youth A never identified any specific staff at that time.
The facility closed their investigation with no findings.
• The facility’s shower procedure policy was reviewed. It is
required that two staff members at all times are present
when youth are showering to ensure no one is alone with
youth. The shower areas are built so that any youth
showering cannot be seen beyond a wall, and there is a
window with an external covering used by staff to ensure
privacy of the youth. There is no video surveillance of the
shower area, but there is an exterior door to the shower
and any staff working that area can be seen on camera.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews of youth and staff as well as
documents reviewed there are no violations found for this rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10149
Section (2) A facility shall provide or make available the following
Description minimum programs and services to residents:
(c) Counseling
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A was denied access to her mental health clinician while
placed at the facility.
Investigation Youth A's parent was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. She
stated that she had heard from Youth A previously that her
therapist had come to have an appointment with her while placed
at the facility and was turned away. In addition, Youth A's parent
stated that the therapist was not able to schedule an appointment
while at the facility that day.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. She
stated that she did not believe she had ever been denied access
to her therapist during her time placed at the facility. She recalled
being informed that her therapist came on a day when there was a
lot going on and was not able to see her, but Youth A did not see
this as a problem.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 03/15/2023. She stated that she had direct involvement with
Youth A and her therapist from the local mental health authority
4

who visited on that date in February as alleged. Supervisor 2
stated that she made the decision jointly with the therapist that
day, to not have Youth A come out of the unit to meet with her
because Youth A was significantly escalated and already had to
be restrained and secluded during times of the day because of
dangerous and chaotic behavior. Part of Supervisor 2’s concern
was that the facility has specified areas where youth meet with
family, attorneys, mental health professionals, etc. and that Youth
A had a history of becoming escalated in those areas of the
building and being aggressive towards those visitors as well as
herself and staff. Supervisor 2 recalled an occurrence in October
2022 where Youth A was in the lobby of the facility with her
mother and other individuals, and she became so escalated that
she injured staff and caused significant property damage and that
staff and security had trouble managing the situation because of
the less secured, public location of the incident. Supervisor 2
stated that it was not safe to have the visiting therapist on the unit
with Youth A that day, even if it was possible that the therapist
might have been able to help de-escalate Youth A. Supervisor 2
recalled that the therapist was agreeable and understanding of
this plan to schedule another time.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews of youth and staff there are no
violations found for this rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health Services; policies and procedures
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth A had prescribed medication that was not provided to her
while placed at the facility.
Investigation Youth A's parent was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
unannounced in person visit to the facility on 03/03/2023. She
stated that back in December Youth A stated that she was not
able to take a prescription, possibly Clonidine, because she had
low bread pressure. Youth A's parent stated that she did not hear
any follow up on this issue afterwards.
Nurse 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
03/13/2023. She confirmed that she does not prescribe the
medication the youth at the facility take, that medication is
prescribed by primary care physicians and psychologists outside
of their facility. She is responsible, however, for managing the
distribution of that medication. Nurse 1 stated that she recalled
5

the issue of Youth A’s medication back in December and
explained. She stated she worked with Youth A’s primary care
physician who required that Youth A’s blood pressure be checked
before taking a new dosage of Clonidine around that time, and
there were several occasions where Youth A’s blood pressure
was not within the specified range to safely take the medication.
After some time monitoring the situation Nurse 1 stated that she
was able to have a lower, and more safe, dosage of the
medication prescribed so it could be provided to Youth A.
Documents reviewed:
• Medical documentation from the facility provided by
Nurse 1 that was consistent with her interview. There
was concern over Youth A’s blood pressure while taking
Clonidine during the month of December. This
documentation confirmed how that was addressed for
Youth A through faxes from the youth’s primary care
physician confirming that the medication administration
should be altered for the youth’s safety. The primary
care physician stated on 12/16/2022 that Clonidine
should be discontinued and then re-instated this
medication at a lower dose on 12/21/2022.
• Medication Administration Record for Youth A for the
month of December 2022. This was consistent with the
instructions provided to the facility by Youth A’s primary
care physician.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews of youth and staff as well as
documents reviewed there are no violations found for this rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
